questions.text: What surgeon is credited for designing the prosthesis seen in the figure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Austin-Moore prosthesis was a large, uncemented femoral stem that didn't use polyethylene. The Austin-Moore prosthesis had fenestrations for self-locking which later became the impetus for biological fixation.
  • These implants were originally used to treat hip fractures and certain cases of degenerative arthritis.
  • The prosthesis has a head with a small neck and a stem. It is available in head sizes ranging from 35 to 59 mm (odd numbers).
  • There is a small hole at the top of the stem for the hook of the extractor, used while removing the prosthesis. The stem has two fenestrations in its middle, through which the bone supposedly grows and helps in fixation of the prosthesis.
  • This prosthesis can thus be used only without cement because the use of cement would make its removal, if required, difficult.

Explanation of Other Options:

John Charnley (Option A)

  • John Charnley introduced the idea of replacing the eroded acetabulum with a Teflon component. Pioneer of the modern total hip replacement (THR)
  • Developed the low-friction arthroplasty using polished metal stem and polyethylene cup, with polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) fixation.

San Baw (Option B)

  • Known primarily for the development of forefoot arthroplasty using ivory composite prostheses in Burma/Myanmar.
  • His work focused on toe joint replacements, not hip implants.

Sir Harry Platt (Option C)

  • A renowned British orthopedic surgeon (early 20th century), known for cerebral palsy & bone infection treatment, as well as establishing orthopedic services.

choices.text: Maintain head of the bed flat with non-weight bearing restrictions
Place the hip in flexion and the knee in extension
Place the hip in extension and the knee in flexion

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman undergoes an uncomplicated right total hip arthroplasty. Preoperatively her right leg length was 2mm shorter than the left side. On the evening of surgery, she has full motor strength and intact sensation. On the morning of postoperative day two she develops an inability to dorsiflex her ankle. There is no wound drainage and her anticoagulation levels are within normal limits. What is the next best step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has developed a sciatic nerve palsy of unknown origin.
  • The hip should be placed in extension and the knee flexed to relax the nerve while reversible causes of the palsy are investigated.
  • Sciatic nerve palsy is the most common nerve palsy following total hip arthroplasty.
  • Symptoms may present immediately post-op suggesting iatrogenic injury (retractor placement, cement heat, injury from cup screw placement, cerclage cabling, direct injury, indirect through excessive lengthening, 'double crush' in the setting of lumbar spondylosis) or may evolve after surgery.
  • The immediate treatment of a new nerve palsy is to limit tension on the nerve by placing the hip in extension and knee in flexion.
  • The patient may then undergo workup for the cause of new nerve palsy.
  • Expeditious axial imaging may be obtained to evaluate for hematoma. Based on clinical judgment the patient may be taken for decompression of hematoma versus reversal of other causes of nerve compression.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Maintain head of the bed flat with non-weight bearing restrictions(Option A): Restricting the patient to head of the bed flat and non-weight bearing would not relieve tension on the sciatic nerve. This may reduce spinal nerve root compression in spinal trauma or epidural hematoma
  • Obtain an EMG(Option B): An EMG(Electromyography) may be indicated eventually, EMG can help localize nerve injury, but only becomes diagnostic 3-4 weeks post-injury due to Wallerian degeneration.
  • Place the hip in flexion and the knee in extension(Option C): Hip flexion and knee extension positioning would put more tension on the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: In Anterolateral approach for hip surgery, intermuscular plane is made between tensor fascia lata and which other muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The plane of dissection in anterolateral approach also known as the Watson-Jones approach to hip is between TFL and gluteus medius

  • Incision: Curvilinear incision centered over the greater trochanter running posteriorly along the shaft of the femur with hip in 30-40° of flexion starting 2-3 cm behind the ASIS.
  • Soft tissue dissection: Plane is developed between the TFL and the gluteus medius (protects the inferior branch of the superior gluteal nerve).
  • TFL is then retracted medial and anterior, and the gluteus medius retracted posterior and lateral exposing gluteus minimus posteriorly and rectus anteriorly.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gluteus Maximus (Option A):

  • Location: It is a large, superficial posterior muscle of the hip.
  • Function: Primary extensor of the hip.
  • Surgical Relevance: It is not part of the anterior or anterolateral approaches.
  • Used in: Posterior (Moore or Southern) approaches, where it is split in line with its fibers.

Gluteus Minimus (Option B):

  • Location: Lies deep to the Gluteus Medius.
  • Function: Assists in hip abduction and internal rotation.
  • Surgical Relevance: Often exposed and may be elevated or incised during anterolateral approaches, but it is not part of the intermuscular plane.

Gemellus (Option D):

  • Location: Deep in the posterior hip, near the short external rotators (along with piriformis, obturator internus).
  • Function: Lateral rotator of the thigh.
  • Surgical Relevance: These are seen in posterior approaches (e.g., Southern or Moore), where they may be detached and later repaired.

questions.text: Risk factors for a motor nerve palsy following primary total hip arthroplasty include all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Certain pre-operative risk factors may place patients at increased risk for the development of nerve injury during primary total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • These include a history of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), limb lengthening, posttraumatic arthritis, cementless femoral fixation, and the posterior approach.

Motor Nerve Palsy in THA: Risk Factors

Explanation of Other Options:

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) (Option A):

  • DDH often involves altered anatomy, soft tissue contractures, and the need for significant limb lengthening, all of which can stretch the sciatic nerve during surgery.
  • Sciatic nerve palsy is more common in Crowe type III-IV dysplasia.

Limb Lengthening (Option B):

  • Excessive lengthening (>2 cm) increases the tension on the sciatic nerve, particularly the peroneal division, which is more vulnerable due to its fixed path near the fibular neck.
  • This is one of the strongest predictors of postoperative motor nerve palsy.

Posttraumatic Arthritis (Option C):

  • These hips may have distorted anatomy, scar tissue, or malunited fractures, making surgical dissection more challenging.
  • The nerve may be tethered or encased in fibrosis, increasing risk during exposure or retraction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic change in cartilage involved in moderate osteoarthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Increased water content is a characteristic change in cartilage involved in moderate osteoarthritis

The changes observed in articular cartilage affected by osteoarthritis include:

  • Increased water content (as a result of the disruption in architecture of the matrix molecules),
  • Decreased quantity of proteoglycans,( Option C ruled out)
  • Decreased quantity of collagen with decreases in cross-linking and stiffness associated with degradation,
  • Increased thickness of subchondral bone,( Option A ruled out)
  • Increased chondrocyte activity and proliferation of chondrocytes.(Option B ruled out)

This is different than the changes seen during the natural aging process which include:

  • Decreased water content,
  • Decreased proteoglycan content and size (decreased length of protein core and GAG chains),
  • Normal quantity of collagen,
  • Increased collagen stiffness and cross-linking,
  • Unchanged chondrocyte activity/proliferation,
  • Unchanged thickness of subchondral bone, and
  • Decreased ratio of chondroitin sulfate to total glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: Which comorbidity is most significantly associated with the early surgical wound complications requiring surgical interventions following primary total knee arthroplasty?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Increased wound complication rates have been associated with diabetes mellitus.
  • Post-operative wound complications following total knee arthroplasty can be potentially devastating to the patient and come at increased care-related costs.
  • Multiple systemic risk factors have been associated, including diabetes mellitus, renal disease, steroid use, and inflammatory arthritis.
  • Additionally, previous open knee surgery can predispose the patient to deleterious outcomes, especially when previous incisions are not incorporated into the approach.
  • Prior to surgery, modifiable risk factors must be addressed to ensure primary wound-healing including smoking cessation, nutritional optimization, and discontinuing any potentially harmful immunomodulating medications.

Explanation of Other Options:

Previous arthroscopic knee surgery(Option B): Open knee surgery, as opposed to arthroscopic knee surgery, has been reported as a risk factor for wound complications, especially when a more medial based incision is used during the arthroplasty procedure. This can result in necrosis of the lateral region of the wound, which may sometimes require a rotational gastrocnemius flap.

Post-operative aspirin DVT prophylaxis(Option C): Deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis with aspirin is associated with fewer wound complications compared to low-molecular-weight heparin and novel oral anticoagulants.

Body mass index of 31 kg/m^2(Option D): Morbid obesity (BMI >40 kg/m^2) has been associated with increased infection rates and wound complications.

choices.text: Surgical intervention after cultures and sensitivity reports
Repeat aspiration of the knee and send for alpha-defensin
IV antibiotic f/b surgical intervention after 48 hours

questions.text: A 66-year-old patient that underwent a right total knee arthroplasty approximately 4 years ago presents with worsening right knee pain over the last 48 hours. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and recently underwent a dental procedure a week ago. Labs were significant for CRP of 212, ESR 105, and a WBC count of 11000. Aspiration yielded a milky-looking fluid with 55000 nucleated cells with 97% PMN. Radiographs are shown in Figures A and B. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with an acute hematogenous prosthetic joint infection, which requires surgical treatment as soon as safely possible.
  • Periprosthetic joint infections (PJI) are generally managed surgically.
  • Diagnosis is composed of a battery of findings as established by the Musculoskeletal Infection Society (MSIS), which requires the presence of one of two major criteria or four of six minor criteria (Illustration A).
  • Acute infections can often be treated with irrigation and debridement with polyethylene exchange (IDPE), whereas chronic infections are best managed with a two-stage revision.

Explanation of Other Options:

Surgical intervention after cultures and sensitivity reports(Option A): Delaying surgical intervention for aspiration cultures to finalize is not recommended. Ideally, surgery should proceed as soon as safely possible.

Repeat aspiration of the knee and send for alpha-defensin(Option B): Repeat aspiration and sending for alpha-defensin would further delay treatment in this patient.

IV antibiotic f/b surgical intervention after 48 hours(Option C): IV antibiotics alone is not sufficient treatment for PJI in patients able to tolerate surgery.

questions.text: What factor is associated with a higher risk of dislocation after total hip arthroplasty?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Previous hip surgery is associated with a higher risk of dislocation after total hip arthroplasty

  • Dislocation after total hip arthroplasty is a multifactorial problem.
  • Numerous risk factors may act independently or cumulatively to increase the risk of this complication. Previous hip surgery of any kind is associated with a twofold increased risk for dislocation.

Other risk factors include

  • Female gender,
  • Impaired mental status,
  • Inflammatory arthritis, and older age.
  • Neuromuscular disorders
  • Improper component position

Numerous studies have shown a lower dislocation rate with a direct lateral approach, although surgical techniques such as capsular repair have significantly lowered the incidence of dislocation after using the posterior approach. Metal-on-metal bearings have been associated with other complications such as adverse tissue reactions but are often used with larger-diameter bearings, which pose a lower risk of dislocation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteoarthritis (Option A):

  • While osteoarthritis is the most common indication for THA, it is actually associated with a lower risk of dislocation compared to:
    • Neuromuscular disorders (e.g. Parkinson's)
    • Hip fracture
    • Inflammatory arthritis

A direct lateral surgical approach (Option C):

  • The direct lateral (Hardinge) approach actually has a lower dislocation rate compared to the posterior approach.
  • This is because the posterior capsule and short external rotators are preserved or repaired during lateral approaches.
  • So this reduces, not increases, dislocation risk.

Metal-on-metal bearing surfaces (Option D):

  • The bearing surface material (metal-on-metal, ceramic-on-polyethylene, etc.) is not a primary factor influencing dislocation risk.
  • It may affect wear or osteolysis long-term, but not joint stability in the immediate postoperative period.

choices.text: Initiation of a first-generation cephalosporin while awaiting culture results.
Initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics while awaiting culture results.
Ultrasound to evaluate for fluid collection around the knee.
Surgical debridement of the knee before culture results are available.

questions.text: A healthy 72-year-old woman is seen 14 days after cemented total knee arthroplasty. She reports increasing pain and swelling for the last 4 days accompanied by 4 days of wound drainage. Examination reveals that she is afebrile, and has erythema and moderate serosanguinous drainage from the wound. The knee is moderately swollen. Aspiration of the knee reveals no organisms on Gram stain. Culture results are expected back in 48 hours. Optimal management should consist of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surgical debridement of the knee before culture results are available is the optimal management.

  • DISCUSSION: Increased pain, swelling, erythema, and drainage 2 weeks removed from the primary arthroplasty are all signs of a probable infection.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein may not be helpful as they are elevated postoperatively even in the absence of infection.
  • Even in the absence of infection, persistent wound drainage is an indication for surgical debridement to prevent subsequent infection.
  • When a postoperative infection is easily recognized by clinical examination, there is no need to wait for a positive culture before proceeding with debridement.

Explanation of Other Options:

Initiation of a first-generation cephalosporin while awaiting culture results (Option A):

  • Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for a suspected early postoperative PJI.
  • Empiric antibiotics can mask culture results if given before debridement.
  • Antibiotics are started after obtaining intraoperative cultures, unless patient is septic.

Initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics while awaiting culture results (Option B):

  • Similar issue: Empiric antibiotics can compromise culture yield.
  • In non-septic patients, surgery should not be delayed in favor of antibiotics.
  • Antibiotics are typically started after samples are obtained intraoperatively.

Ultrasound to evaluate for fluid collection around the knee (Option C):

  • Not needed here - already clear clinical signs of infection and knee has been aspirated.
  • Ultrasound is not standard for diagnosing deep prosthetic joint infection.
  • MRI is also limited due to artifact from the prosthesis.

choices.text: Deep branch of lateral femoral circumflex artery
Superficial branch of the medial femoral circumflex artery
Deep branch of the medial femoral circumflex artery

questions.text: During surgical hip dislocation for the management of femoral acetabular impingement, preservation of what structure is paramount to maintaining vascularity to the femoral head?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When a trochanteric osteotomy is performed with the desire to maintain vascularity to the femoral head, as in the approach for a surgical hip dislocation, the deep branch of the medial femoral circumflex artery must be maintained.
  • This branch courses along the posterior aspect of the greater trochanter, posterior to the tendon of obturator externus, and anterior to the tendons of superior gemellus, obturator internus, and inferior gemellus.
  • It perforates the capsule above the superior gemellus and distal to the tendon or piriformis, before dividing into two to four terminal retinacular branches.
  • Maintaining the attachment of the external rotators maintains the blood supply to the femoral head.
  • Additionally, the superior-lateral retinacular vessels must also be maintained during femoral neck osteoplasty.

Explanation of Other Options:

Deep branch of lateral femoral circumflex artery (Option A)

  • Supplies anterior thigh musculature and may contribute to the anterior hip capsule.
  • Has minimal contribution to femoral head vascularity in adults.

Medial epiphyseal artery (Option B)

  • An older anatomical term, now less commonly used in adult hip vascular anatomy.
  • Often confused with branches of the MFCA, but not specifically identified or preserved in modern surgical approaches.

Superficial branch of the medial femoral circumflex artery (Option C)

  • This supplies soft tissues and posterior structures, not the retinacular arteries entering the femoral head.
  • It's not the critical branch to preserve during surgical dislocation.

questions.text: Below Figure shows the radiograph of a healthy 52-year-old woman who has severe right hip pain that has been unresponsive to nonsurgical management. What is the most appropriate surgical procedure at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has developmental dysplasia of the right hip, as can be noted by the shallow acetabulum and lack of femoral head coverage.
  • She also has secondary osteoarthritis, manifested radiographically by joint space narrowing, periarticular sclerosis, and subchondral acetabular cyst formation.
  • Femoral and/or acetabular redirectional osteotomies are most effective when performed before the onset of osteoarthritis.
  • After osteoarthritis has set in, total hip arthroplasty is the most reliable procedure for reducing pain.
  • Hemiarthroplasties are not indicated in the presence of arthritic changes of the acetabulum.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for total joint replacement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Recent or current joint sepsis is the absolute contraindication for total joint replacement

Contraindication for replacement surgery -

questions.text: Most common cause of death after total hip replacement is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Most common cause of death after THR is MI > Pulmonary embolism. As MI is not given among the options, the best answer is pulmonary embolism.

  • Most common fatal postoperative complication.
  • Can present suddenly with:
    • Dyspnea
    • Chest pain
    • Hypoxia
    • Cardiac arrest in severe cases
  • PE usually results from DVT in the lower limbs, often asymptomatic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Infection ( Option A):

  • Periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) is a major complication, but:
    • Usually not acutely fatal
    • More likely to cause morbidity than mortality
  • Requires revision surgery but typically does not lead directly to death.

Deep vein thrombosis ( Option C):

  • DVT is a common complication but not usually fatal by itself.
  • However, it predisposes to PE.
  • DVT is a cause, not the cause of death - PE is the fatal outcome.

Fat embolism ( Option D):

  • Seen more often in trauma and long bone fractures, not elective THR.
  • Rare in joint replacement and less common than PE.

questions.text: Which structure is at risk when we place the Hohmann retractor along the anterior rim of the acetabulum, during a total hip replacement surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Placement of a curved cobra or Hohmann retractor in the interval between the anterior rim of the acetabulum and the psoas tendon puts the femoral nerve and vessels at risk.
  • Erroneous placement of this retractor over the psoas muscle can cause injury to the femoral nerve or adjacent vessels.
  • The risk increases with a more inferior placement of the retractor.
  • The safest position is near the level of the anterior superior iliac spine.
  • Neurapraxia or permanent damage to the femoral nerve
  • Vascular injury, hematoma, or even pseudoaneurysm from femoral artery compression or laceration

Explanation of Other Options:

Psoas tendon (Option B):

  • Lies medial and deep, but injury to the psoas tendon usually causes tendinopathy or irritation, not neurovascular damage.
  • Not the most at-risk structure with anterior rim retractor placement.

External iliac artery and vein (Option C):

  • Located superior and lateral to the acetabulum, deeper and more intrapelvic.
  • Typically not at risk with anterior rim retraction - unless very high or deeply placed.

Obturator artery (Option D):

  • Arises from the internal iliac artery, runs through the obturator foramen, medial to the acetabulum.
  • Can be at risk during medial wall penetration, not anterior rim retraction.

choices.text: CRP, ESR, Neutrophil count of synovial fluid

questions.text: Which is not a correct constellation of markers for post arthroplasty prosthetic joint infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Markers for post arthroplasty joint infection

  1. ESR and CRP currently remain as first-line screening tests for periprosthetic joint infection (PJI). They have high sensitivity and low specificity. CRP is more sensitive and specific than ESR.
  2. Interleukin-6 (IL-6)- IL-6 is an inflammatory cytokine produced by stimulated monocytes and macrophages. It induces the production of acute-phase proteins, including CRP.
  3. White blood cell count (WBC)- While synovial WBC count and differential is one of the main diagnostic criteria for PJI, serum WBC count has very little utility.
  4. Procalcitonin (PCT)- It is a protein produced by neuroendocrine cells and the parafollicular cells of the thyroid under physiological conditions. In sepsis, the main producers of PCT are macrophages and monocytic cells of different organs, especially the liver. PCT has a high diagnostic accuracy for the identification of systemic infection but for joint infection it has low sensitivity and diagnostic accuracy.
  5. D-dimer- Serum D-dimer has been shown to outperform other conventional tests such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein in diagnosis of PJI. It has sensitivity and specificity higher than the ESR and CRP and has emerged as a promising tool for diagnosis of PJI.
  6. Tumor necrosis factor-alfa (TNF-alfa)- It has high specificity and low sensitivity for PJI. Technical drawbacks include long processing times (over two hours) and the instability of the sample, which means it needs to be processed within 60 minutes of being drawn. Therefore, based on these results, TNF-a is not an ideal serum screening test for PJI.
  7. Intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) is a membrane glycoprotein that plays a key role in leukocyte migration and activation that has also been studied in the context of PJI. It may also be considered as good markers of infection, as measurement of its levels allows for differentiating patients with and without infection, and between patients with infection and those with previous infection, since marker levels quickly return to baseline values after clearance of the infection.
